{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3480324,"name":"Team 571 Build Mentor","username":"RedRackham","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/e9c0ed/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-12T21:05:44.290Z","cooked":"

Does anyone have ideas on how to mechanically algin an L2-L3 scoring mechanism on an elevator with a branch? I haven’t seen this discussed yet and was curious what people think.

Background:
We are a low resource team with limited programming. We just got swerve running in December and still need to tune it. We have a Limelight 3G but have never used it and aren’t sure we’ll be able to get auto align working. Even if we do , we don’t know if it will be accurate enough align with the branches to score coral quickly.

Design
We’re planning on having a hopper feed a fixed orientation scoring mechanism on a single stage elevator. We’d thought we’d pivot the mechanism so it can adjust left and right by a few inches. Our first idea was to use a metal plate with a V-shaped notch in it, similar to FTC team 14481 (mentioned here in Team Ri3D 1.0’s Strategy and Insight video).

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-12T21:05:44.290Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":52,"reads":515,"readers_count":514,"score":378.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":481265,"topic_slug":"mechanical-branch-alignment","display_username":"Team 571 Build Mentor","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://youtu.be/yExxx9wSM9Y?si=PAaIzUVhDw44iRsL&t=178","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":19}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":41864,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/mechanical-branch-alignment/481265/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3480771,"name":"","username":"Spaceman","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/s/a5b964/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T07:08:31.679Z","cooked":"

While I can’t think of a good mechanical solution, having a webcam centered with your scoring mech that is streamed to your ds could be a very simple way to align albeit manually.

While not mechanical, take a look at the “automatic alignment concept”

It’s pretty easy from a programming and build standpoint, as the sensors are cheap, and easy to install. Both in terms of wiring and code.

FRC 2491 NoMythic| 2025 Build Thread| Open Alliance FRC Open Alliance
Prototypes round 2 Take a look through our prototypes day 2! More updates on the Algae, and coral angles and pickup! [Prototypes Day 2] Automatic alignment concept [image] (more information, in PDF linked below) Essentially: On the end of the robot that we will address the reef with, there are four sensors. In this case they are tight beam laser time-of-flight sensors with a beamwidth of 6-15 degrees. For each reef branch, there is a tolerance range across which we could hypothe…

without auto aligning to the april tags, I’d recommend targeting l1 and algae. It’s certainly possible to score well without vision, but you’ll be a lot slower, and once the close side of the reef fills up, you’re out of luck

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-13T07:45:47.028Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":374,"readers_count":373,"score":79.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":481265,"topic_slug":"mechanical-branch-alignment","display_username":" Sean Paxman I 9191","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":53018,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"- 4788 | 9191 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/mechanical-branch-alignment/481265/4","custom_user_title":"- 4788 | 9191 Mentor","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3480795,"name":"Nick Foote","username":"Footie","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/footie/{size}/218325_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T08:04:06.744Z","cooked":"

So, I was thinking about the V-shape lineup as well, and unfortunately, the tilted scoring pipes make it much harder. If you try to use the V-shape on the straight up and down part, that doesn’t actually align you with the scoring peg. I made this ms paint explaination. This is a top down view, with the back purple circle being the main vertical pole, and the bottom purple pipe being the end of the L2/3 pipe. The grey circle is the coral, I hope the rest is self explanatory.

image1743×1081 11.4 KB

So the V method would work on L4 where the pipe is vertical, but not L2-3. Maybe there’s a way to have you V-shape be tilted upwards and try to align directly with the scoring peg, but having your mechanical line up not be in the same plane as the travel of the robot seems like a nightmare.

Been posting this bot a lot.

There is a great complient alignment mechanism that could be adapted here:

The Blue Alliance

Stryke Force - Team 2767 (2019)

FIRST Robotics Competition team from Kalamazoo, Michigan, USA.

This was student work in its purest form, this end effector was so fun to watch develop over the season. Mentors just supplied the parts orders and brought in the parts the students sent to the printer.

Could you elaborate more? I couldn’t tell what the compliant mechanism was from watching videos.

The behind the bumpers and robozone videos show this off, specifically the whole triangle being able to compress and move left and right on the polycarb springs.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-01-13T15:24:11.523Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":7,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":236,"readers_count":235,"score":92.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":481265,"topic_slug":"mechanical-branch-alignment","display_username":"Skye Leake","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SJ-yE_yEDnY","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":53784,"username":"Max_Morehead","name":"Max Morehead","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/max_morehead/{size}/231937_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":true,"admin":false,"staff":true,"user_id":19235,"hidden":false,"trust_level":4,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Pretengineer"},"post_url":"/t/mechanical-branch-alignment/481265/8","custom_user_title":"Pretengineer","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3},{"id":"open_mouth","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3480981,"name":"usbcd36","username":"usbcd36","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/usbcd36/{size}/2444_2.png","created_at":"2025-01-13T16:09:01.497Z","cooked":"

Seems like it could work if the mechanism translates with the alignment fork (instead of pivoting), and if the robot’s bumpers are pressed flat against the reef wall.

I do wonder where the line between “this is just touching the reef” and “this is grasping/grabbing/attaching-to it” will be drawn. I imagine this can only partially be answered by Q&A too.

Thanks for all the ideas!

@Spaceman We already had the webcam idea as a backup. Is the resolution and update speed fast enough to use for driving?

@trixydevs I really like this idea! I missed it in my alignment research. It could be made really simple by reducing it to one sensor left and right. The driver just needs to hit the reef base close to the center and an operator can translate the robot till the sensor changes. If the translation speed is slow enough, it should be pretty repeatable. It has a big advantage in being two static sensors inside the frame perimeter as opposed to a pivoting/translating mechanism outside the frame.

@usbcd36 Good point with G147 and potentially getting a foul for ‘grabbing.’
